awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometer for Collaborative Research in Geochemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometer (ICP-MS) to support a new collaborative Geochemistry Research Group, consisting of new and senior faculty in the Department of Geological and Environmental Sciences at California State University, Chico, a Hispanic Serving Institution.  The instrument will support trace element analyses that will facilitate cross-disciplinary research related to the geochemistry of the Earth by faculty, undergraduates and M.S. students.  Access to an on-campus ICP-MS will facilitate undergraduate research in geochemistry by providing students with hands-on analytical experience.  The investigators have significant combined experience mentoring non-traditional, underrepresented undergraduate independent STEM research projects, from initial development through presentation at regional or national meetings and publications. The ICP-MS will be incorporated into over 20 classes in the College of Natural Sciences and the College of Agriculture, giving a wide range of student users state-of-the-art analytical experience. In association with the Gateway Science Museum, the Geochemistry Research Group will set up a Citizen Science project to assess water quality in the Chico area.  This support is congruent with NSFs mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing the national health, prosperity and welfare given the societal relevance of targeted environmental research aimed at understanding the terrestrial water cycle with implications for improved water resource management and the impact of the acquisition on training the next generation scientific workforce. 

The ICP-MS will support NSF-funded projects in geochemistry and other current collaborations of the research group but, more importantly, it will enable new multidisciplinary collaborations in three main foci: Aqueous Biogeochemistry, Geochemistry of Ore Deposits and Mine Reclamation; and Petrology. The research group is currently engaged in a variety of research including: the role of iron in biogeochemical cycling, mediating urban storm-water runoff by biofiltration, mineralization of Gold (Au) bearing deposits, assessing soil and water contamination from historic mining, metasomatism of stromatolites, and the petrogenetic evolution of a chain of basaltic volcanoes.  New projects in development include studies of surface water quality in Lassen Volcanic National Park (California), impacts of volcanic fluids and gases on surrounding soils and vegetation, and petrology of the largest eruptive unit (the Lovejoy Basalt) identified in California.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded the acquisition of an Inductively-Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometer (ICPMS) at California State University, Chico. This is the first instrument of its kind on campus. The ICPMS is used to determine the chemical elements present in different substances, and their concentrations. Before being introduced to the instrument, samples must be ground up and digested in acid, and the diluted acid solution is then analyzed.

 Earth and Environmental Sciences faculty, undergraduate and graduate students are now able to analyze research samples on campus using this ICPMS. Students have been trained to use this state-of-the-art instrument and have been involved in troubleshooting when unexpected issues have arisen. So far, one thesis and three conference presentations have resulted from data collected on this instrument, but many more journal articles, conference presentations and theses are anticipated in the near future. Several labs using the ICPMS have also been designed for courses in chemistry, environmental science and geology, allowing students to collect and analyze their own data in class.

 In addition to research and classes, the ICPMS has also been used in a citizen science project in collaboration with the Gateway Science Museum close to campus. In summer and fall 2021, the museum facilitated weekly water sampling sessions run by a student scientist and attended by members of the public. Samples were collected from Big Chico Creek, which runs between the Museum and campus. The scientist showed how to collect the sample and demonstrated the different types of data that could be recorded using this sample, including geochemical analysis with the ICPMS. This important work has provided data on the baseline conditions of Big Chico Creek through the dry and rainy seasons, which was previously unknown. These data have already been used in classes and have been showcased to the public at a campus open day.

 


Last Modified: 03/13/2023
Modified by: Hannah Aird
